content: How can I help you today?

I've been having trouble sleeping lately. My thoughts just keep racing at night, and it’s been hard to shut them off. Work has been really stressful, and I’m constantly worried about losing my job and not being able to take care of my family. My partner thought talking to someone might help, but I’m not really sure what to expect here.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like this has been a challenging time for you, with sleepless nights and stress weighing heavily on your mind. Work pressure and concern for your family are clearly very important to you, and it must feel overwhelming to manage all of that while trying to rest. Talking here might be a space to explore what’s been going on and see what might help ease some of those racing thoughts. What do you think about taking this step to talk through it?

I don’t know, honestly. I feel like talking isn’t going to solve my work problems, you know? But at the same time, I’m willing to give it a try if it might help me sleep better and not feel so drained all the time. I just don’t know if this will make a difference.

It makes sense to feel that way—work challenges can feel like they’re out of your control, and it might seem like talking won’t change much. At the same time, it sounds like you value the possibility of sleeping better and feeling more energized, even if you're unsure how to get there. Giving this a try could give you space to explore what’s weighing on you and discover steps that might make a difference. What would you hope to get out of this conversation as a start?

I’m not even sure what I hope to get out of this. I guess if I could quiet my thoughts enough to actually sleep, that would be something. The rest just feels so big that I don’t even know where to begin.

It sounds like finding some calm in your thoughts and improving your ability to sleep feels like a more manageable place to start right now. The bigger stressors, like work and family, might seem overwhelming, but even small steps toward better sleep could make a difference in how you're feeling overall. It's okay not to know exactly where to begin—you're here, and that's already an important step. Do you want to talk more about what's keeping your thoughts racing at night or explore ways that might help you feel more at ease before bed?

It sounds like finding some calm in your thoughts and improving your ability to sleep feels like a more manageable place to start right now. The bigger stressors, like work and family, might seem overwhelming, but even small steps toward better sleep could make a difference in how you're feeling overall. It's okay not to know exactly where to begin—you're here, and that's already an important step. Do you want to talk more about what's keeping your thoughts racing at night or explore ways that might help you feel more at ease before bed?
All right. So tell me more about the thoughts that tend to keep you up at night. What’s on your mind when nighttime comes?

It's mostly work stuff—like wondering if I’ll get everything done, if my boss is happy with me, or if layoffs are coming. I keep running scenarios in my head, and I just can’t shut it off. Then I start thinking about how my family would manage if I lost my job, and it’s like a spiral that doesn’t stop.

That sounds exhausting—having your mind stuck in a cycle of worry about work and your family’s well-being. It shows how much you care about providing for them and doing well at your job, but being unable to turn those thoughts off must take a toll on your energy and peace. What have you tried so far to quiet those thoughts or cope with this spiral?

That sounds exhausting—having your mind stuck in a cycle of worry about work and your family’s well-being. It shows how much you care about providing for them and doing well at your job, but being unable to turn those thoughts off must take a toll on your energy and peace. What have you tried so far to quiet those thoughts or feel more at ease?

Mostly, I just try to distract myself, like watching TV or scrolling on my phone until I’m too tired to keep my eyes open. Sometimes I’ll try breathing exercises or counting, but those don’t always work. It feels like the worry just hangs around no matter what I do.

Mostly, I just try to distract myself—watching TV, scrolling on my phone, or lying there waiting to pass out from exhaustion, but that doesn’t always work. Occasionally I’ll try deep breaths or counting sheep, but honestly, nothing seems to stop the worrying. It’s like I’m stuck in a loop with no way out.

It sounds like you’ve tried a few things to find relief, like distraction or calming techniques, but the worry feels persistent no matter what. Being stuck in that loop can make it harder to feel like anything will help, yet you're here and open to exploring options, which shows your willingness to try—a real strength during such a frustrating time. What do you think would need to happen for that loop to feel less overwhelming?

It sounds like you’ve tried a lot on your own, and I can understand how frustrating it must be when nothing seems to break that loop. The fact that you’re here shows that you care about finding a way forward, even if it’s hard to imagine right now. Maybe we can try to figure out what’s feeding that loop or explore small changes that could give your mind some relief—how does that sound?

Exploring what’s feeding that loop or making small changes might help, but honestly, I don’t know what needs to happen to feel better. Maybe if I had more job security, I wouldn’t worry so much. But since I can’t control that, I guess I need to figure out how to handle the stress better.

It makes sense that job security feels like the root of this stress—it’s a big thing to have hanging over your head, especially when it affects your family. The fact that you’re open to finding ways to handle the stress is a good place to start, even if it feels hard right now. Is there anything in particular you’ve thought about trying but haven’t yet, or would you like some suggestions?
Not really—I haven’t thought much about what else to try. I’m open to suggestions though, if you have ideas.

It’s great that you’re open to trying new things. I’m wondering if we could start with simple steps to help calm your mind in the evenings, like setting a routine to wind down before bed or writing down your thoughts and worries so they’re not swirling in your head all night. How do you feel about trying something like that?
That sounds okay, I guess. A routine might help, and I’ve heard of writing things down before, but I’ve never actually tried it. I’m not sure how much of a difference it would make, though.
